statement.tex: \text{If }\ora{a}=\vector{x}{2}{-z}\text{ and }\ora{b}=\vector{3}{-y}{1} \\ \text{are two equal vectors, then write the value of } \\ x+y+z.

step.context: \text{If }\ora{a}=\vector{x}{2}{-z}\text{ and }\ora{b}=\vector{3}{-y}{1} \\ %text for $\ora{a}$ to be equal to $\ora{b}$, is the following sufficient? %
step.reason: %text A vector has {\bf magnitude} and{\bf direction}. $|\ora{a}|=|\ora{b}|$ only takes care of the magnitude part. It does not guarantee that the vectors point in the same direction. %

%text If two vectors are to have the same magnitude and direction, they must have identical $\imath$, $\jmath$ and ${\it k}$ components. %
\qquad\begin{align} \ora{a}&=\vector{x}{2}{-z} \\ \ora{b}&=\vector{3}{-y}{1} \\ \end{align} \\
%text Comparing coefficients of $\hat i$, $\hat j$ and $\hat k$ we get, $x=3, y=-2, z=-1$ % \therefore x+y+z=0
